content.body: shu: re: https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/pull/2548, it looks like very nearly every `!`-prefixed call gets the user-code effect suppressed (possibly actually all of them?). maybe worth building that heuristic into ecmarkup?
content.formatted_body: shu: re: https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/pull/2548, it looks like very nearly every !-prefixed call gets the user-code effect suppressed (possibly actually all of them?). maybe worth building that heuristic into ecmarkup?

content.body: bakkot: almost all, yes. worth thinking about building it in. it puts the burden of vigilance on us (the PR reviewers) to remember to check if a `!` shouldn't be suppressed. otherwise it puts the burden on authors
content.formatted_body: bakkot: almost all, yes. worth thinking about building it in. it puts the burden of vigilance on us (the PR reviewers) to remember to check if a ! shouldn't be suppressed. otherwise it puts the burden on authors

content.body: putting it on us is probably the right choice

bakkot: Michael Ficarra oh, for the "*default*" stuff, the point is that "*default*" is used only as a [[LocalName]] and not as an [[ExportName]] in ExportEntry Records, and therefore is not user visible?
content.formatted_body: bakkot: Michael Ficarra oh, for the "default" stuff, the point is that "default" is used only as a [[LocalName]] and not as an [[ExportName]] in ExportEntry Records, and therefore is not user visible?

content.body: so if a module exports a value named `"*default*"`, that could be imported, since the magical [[ExportName]] name is `"default"`, which has always been user exposed?
content.formatted_body: so if a module exports a value named "*default*", that could be imported, since the magical [[ExportName]] name is "default", which has always been user exposed?
